metadata.title: Disinfection of SARS-CoV-2 contaminated surfaces of personal items with UVC-LED disinfection boxes

abstract.text: The severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is transmitted from person-27 to-person by close contact, small aerosol respiratory droplets and potentially via contact with 28 contaminated surfaces. Here, we investigated the effectiveness of commercial UVC-LED 29 disinfection boxes in inactivating SARS-CoV-2 contaminated surfaces of personal items. We 30 contaminated glass, metal and plastic samples representing the surfaces of personal items such 31 as smartphones, coins or credit cards with SARS-CoV-2 formulated in an organic matrix 32 mimicking human respiratory secretions. For disinfection, the samples were placed at different 33 distances from UVC emitting LEDs inside commercial UVC-LED disinfection boxes and irradiated 34 for different time periods (up to 10 minutes). High viral loads of SARS-CoV-2 were effectively 35 inactivated on all surfaces after 3 minutes of irradiation. Even 10 seconds of UVC-exposure 36 strongly reduced viral loads. Thus, UVC-LED boxes proved to be an effective method for 37 disinfecting SARS-CoV-2 contaminated surfaces that are typically found on personal items. 38 * * * P < 0.001. TCID50=tissue culture infectious dose, 50%; EC90=90% effective concentration. 227

body_text.text: SARS-CoV-2 working stocks (5 × 10 6 TCID50/mL for UVC-LED box 1; 2 x 10 6 TCID50/mL for UVC-86 LED box 2) were diluted in a defined organic matrix mimicking respiratory secretions (9). In brief, 87 900 µL of the respective virus stock was added to 100 µL organic matrix consisting of 2.5 mg/mL 88 mucin type I-S, 7.8 mg/mL BSA Fraction V and 11 mg/mL yeast extract (all Sigma-Aldrich, 89
body_text.section: UVC-LED decontamination of SARS-CoV-2 contaminated surfaces 85

body_text.text: Darmstadt, Germany). Before inoculating the respective virus suspension to glass, metal and 90 plastic carriers, the carriers were sterilized with a UV-lamp emitting 1940 µW/cm 2 UVC at 254 nm 91 (UV-4 S/L, Herolab, Wiesloch, Germany) (7). After sterilizing, 50 µL of the respective virus 92 suspension were placed on the center of the carriers and allowed to dry for 1 h at room 93 temperature. The carriers were positioned at different distances from the UVC-LEDs inside the 94 UVC-LED boxes (UVC-LED box 1: 1 cm and 5 cm horizontal distance; UVC-LED box 2: 1 cm and 95 4 cm vertical distance). The carriers were irradiated for specific durations (0 s, 10 s, 30 s, 1 min, 96 3 min and 10 min). Subsequently, the infectious virus was recovered by vortexing the carriers 97 placed in plastic containers (SARSTEDT, Nümbrecht, Germany) filled with 2 mL DMEM for 1 98 minute. As control, the virus was recovered 10 minutes after drying without irradiation. The 99 experiments were conducted in triplicates and the viral loads were determined by endpoint dilution 100 according to Spearman and Kärber. The means, standard deviations of the viral titers and 90% 101 effective concentration (EC90) values were calculated with GraphPad Prism 9 (GraphPad 102 Software, San Diego, CA). The statistical significances were determined with the t-test. 103

body_text.section: UVC-LED decontamination of SARS-CoV-2 contaminated surfaces 85

body_text.text: SARS-CoV-2 can potentially be transmitted via virus-contaminated surfaces of personal items 107 such as smartphones, keys, coins or credit cards that have been contaminated with the virus. We 108 investigated the performance of two commercially available UVC-LED boxes for virus inactivation 109 on surfaces typically found on personal belongings such as glass, metal and plastic. We used two 110 different UVC-LED boxes for sterilizing, one with lateral UVC-LEDs (Fig. 1A) and one with UVC-111

LEDs incorporated in the lid of the box (Fig. 1B) . Additionally, a mirror was installed to the bottom 112 of the chamber. For UVC-LED box 1, the emitted light intensity was determined with 245 µW/cm 2 113 at horizontal distance of 1 cm and 65 µW/cm 2 in the center of the box at horizontal distance of 5 114 cm from the UVC-LEDs (Corresponding to 0.245 mJ/cm 2 and 0.065 mJ/cm 2 per second, 115 respectively; Fig. 2A ). For both distances, the peak wavelength emission was measured at around 116 254 nm. For UVC-LED box 2, the emitted light intensity was measured with 117 µW/cm 2 at 1 cm 117 vertical distance from the LEDs, which corresponds to 0.117 mJ/cm 2 per second (Fig. 2B ). The 118 peak wavelength emission was detected at 280 nm. 119

Next, metal, glass or plastic samples were overlaid with SARS-CoV-2 diluted in an organic matrix 120 mimicking respiratory secretions. The final calculated virus concentration on the samples was 4.5 121 × 10 6 TCID50/mL for UVC-LED box 1 and 1.8 x 10 6 TCID50/mL for UVC-LED box 2, respectively. 122

Compared to the viral load immediately after drying, there was no significant reduction of the viral 123 loads after 10 minutes without irradiation (Fig. 3) . 124 UVC-LED irradiation conducted with UVC-LED boxes proved to be an appropriate method for the 125 disinfection of SARS-CoV-2 contaminated surfaces. SARS-CoV-2 contaminated glass, metal or 126 plastic samples were effectively UVC-disinfected inside of both UVC-LED boxes ( Fig. 3 and 4) . A 127 significant reduction of viral loads of SARS-CoV-2 on glass, metal and plastic was achieved even 128 after 10 seconds of irradiation (UVC-LED box 1: 2.45 mJ/cm 2 ; UVC-LED box 2: 1.17 mJ/cm 2 ) at 129 a distance of 1 cm from the LEDs in both UVC-LED boxes (Fig. 3) . When using UVC-LED box 1, 130 complete inactivation of SARS-CoV-2 could be achieved after 3 (glass and plastic) or 10 minutes 131 (metal) of irradiation at a distance of 1 cm ( Fig. 3A and 4A) . At a distance of 5 cm from the LEDs 132 with other studies that report susceptibility of coronaviruses, including SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-155

CoV-2 to UVC irradiation (7, 10). To almost completely inactivate high viral loads of SARS-CoV-156 1, a UVC-dose of 1446 mJ/cm 2 was necessary (10). High viral loads of SARS-CoV-2 could be 157 completely inactivated by a UVC dose of 1048 mJ/cm 2 (7). The results of the present study show 158 that the distance of the inoculated materials from the LEDs and thus the emitted light intensity is 159 a decisive factor for achieving the complete inactivation of SARS-CoV-2. Accordingly, recently it LEDs. Light doses at 4 cm distance cannot be shown, as an irradiance measurement of the LEDs 224 at that distance would have required drilling a hole into the bottom of the box, which was not 225 possible without damaging the box. FIGREF0.text: Glass: 88.27±1.49%, metal: 88.26±3.32%, plastic: 90±1.38%; 10 minutes: Glass: 134 91.92±1.85%, metal: 98.52±0.42%, plastic: 92.56±1.7%; Fig. 4A). When using UVC-LED box 2, 135 SARS-CoV-2 was almost completely inactivated after 3 and 10 minutes of irradiation at a distance 136 of 1 cm (3 minutes: Glass: 97.49±0.35%, metal: 99.21±0.1%, plastic: 98.74±0.16%; 10 minutes: 137 Glass: 97.85±0.27%, metal: 99.42±0.08%, plastic: 99.46%; Fig. 4B). At a distance of 4 cm, SARS-138 CoV-2 was completely inactivated on glass and metal and almost completely on plastic 139 (99.89±0.2%) after 10 minutes of irradiation (Fig. 3B and 4B). 140 Taken together, our data demonstrate that UVC-LED sterilization boxes can effectively inactivate 141 SARS-CoV-2 on surfaces such as glass, plastic or metal. 142 143 Discussion 144 SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted through direct contact with infected individuals, by virus-containing 145 aerosols and potentially via contact with virus-contaminated surfaces (3). In the present study, we 146 investigated the performance of UVC-LED sterilization boxes on the inactivation of SARS-COV-147 2 on surfaces such as glass, metal and plastics that are typically found on personal items like 148 smart phones, credit cards or keys. We demonstrated that UVC-LED boxes can effectively 149 inactivate SARS-CoV-2 on glass, metal and plastic. Independent of the used UVC-LED box and 150 the materials, SARS-CoV-2 could be almost completely inactivated after 3 minutes exposure 151 (UVC-LED box 1: 1 cm: 44.1 mJ/cm 2 , 5 cm: 11.7 mJ/cm 2 ; UVC-LED box 2: 1cm: 21.06 mJ/cm 2 ), 152 which represents the standard exposure time provided by the UVC-LED boxes. Even 10 seconds 153 of exposure strongly reduced viral loads on the contaminated surfaces. The findings are in line 154

FIGREF1.text: 160 has been reported that distance and angle of UVC light source in closed box systems are 161 important factors for irradiance over respirator surfaces (11). UVC-LED box 1 and 2 showed a 162 similar reduction of viral load for the materials glass and plastic. At a distance of 5 cm from the 163 LED of UVC-LED box 1, although the viral load was reduced by 91.92±1.85% on glass, 164 98.52±0.42% on metal and 92.56±1.7% on plastic, the emitted light intensity (65 µW/cm 2 ) was 165 not sufficient to completely inactivate the virus after 10 minutes exposure. The mirror at the bottom 166 of UVC-LED box 2 may have contributed to facilitate the inactivation of the virus. Van Doremalen 167 et al. (4) indicated that a SARS-CoV-2 stock with a viral concentration of 10 5 TCID50/mL 168 corresponds to cycle-threshold values between 20 and 22, which is similar to the thresholds of 169 samples from the upper and lower respiratory tracts of infected individuals. In this study, SARS-170 CoV-2 stocks with even higher viral concentrations of about 10 6 TCID50/mL were used for the 171 inoculation of the materials. Overall, both UVC-LED boxes were highly effective in inactivating the 172 high titer viral stocks of SARS-CoV-2. These encouraging results make the UVC-LED boxes an 173 affordable option for the public to disinfect a variety of items, including phones, watches, 174 headphones, masks, makeup utensils, as long as the item size fits the device. As SARS-CoV-2 175 can also be detected on different surfaces in hospital environment (12, 13), UVC-LED boxes might 176 also be an effective tool for environmental decontamination in hospitals. Schematic illustrations of the UVC-LED boxes used for UVC-disinfection. A) UVC-195 LED box 1 (Horcol) was equipped with lateral UVC-LEDs. B) UV-LED box 2 (expondo GmbH, 196 Berlin, Germany) was equipped with UVC-LEDs incorporated in the lid and a mirror installed at 197 the bottom of the chamber.198

FIGREF2.text: Spectrum of the emitted light intensity by LEDs inside of the UVC-LED boxes. 200The emitted light energy was measured by using a radiometrically calibrated spectrometer (STS-201 UV-L-50-400-SMA, Ocean Optics B.V., Ostfildern, Germany) with a sensitivity range between 190 202 and 650 nm (1.5 nm resolution) equipped with a CC-3-UV-S corrector (Ocean Optics B.V., 203 Ostfildern, Germany). A) The spectrum of emitted light intensity of UVC-LED box 1 was measured 204 at 1 and 5 cm horizontal distance from the lateral UVC-LEDs. B) The spectrum of emitted light 205 intensity of UVC-LED box 2 was measured at 1 cm vertical distance from the UVC-LEDs. Emitted 206 light intensity (µW/cm 2 ) between 250 and 280 nm is displayed for each spectrum. Schematic 207 illustrations indicate the borehole and the UVC-detector placed inside of the box for the respective 208 Disinfection of SARS-CoV-2 contaminated objects by two distinct UVC-LED 215 boxes. Glass, metal and plastic samples were contaminated with SARS-CoV-2 at a final 216 concentration of 4.5 × 10 6 TCID50/mL for UVC-LED box 1 and 1.8 x 10 6 TCID50/mL for UVC-LED 217 box 2 in a cell culture medium mixed with defined organic matrix, thereby mimicking the viral 218 contamination on the surfaces of personal belongings such as smartphones, keys, coins or credit 219 cards. The samples were exposed to LED-UVC light for 0 s, 10 s, 30 s, 1 min, 3 min and 10 min 220 at different distances from UVC-LEDs inside the UVC-LED boxes. Experiments were conducted 221 in triplicates. A) In UVC-LED box 1, samples were irradiated at a distance of 1 cm and 5 cm from 222 the UVC-LEDs. B) In UVC-LED box 2, samples were irradiated at 1 cm and 4 cm from the UVC-223

FIGREF3.text: Percentage of inactivation of SARS-CoV-2 on surfaces after 3 or 10 minutes of 229 UVC-LED irradiation. Glass, metal and plastic samples were contaminated with SARS-CoV-2 at 230 a final concentration of 4.5 × 10 6 TCID50/mL for UVC-LED box 1 and 1.8 x 10 6 TCID50/mL for UVC-231 LED box 2 in cell culture medium mixed with defined organic matrix, thereby mimicking the viral 232 contamination on the surfaces of personal belongings such as smartphones, keys, coins or credit 233 cards. The samples were exposed to LED-UVC light for 0 s, 10 s, 30 s, 1 min, 3 min and 10 min 234 at different distances from UVC-LEDs inside the UVC-LED boxes. Experiments were conducted 235 in triplicates. A) In UVC-LED box 1, samples were irradiated at 1 and 5 cm from the UV-C LEDs. 236 B) In UVC-LED box 2, samples were irradiated at 1 and 4 cm from the UV-C LEDs. Data are 237 displayed as mean ± SD. 238
